questions.question_text:
In a 10-node hybrid vSAN cluster, each node has seven 4TB magnetic disks and one 2TB SSD.
What is the raw storage capacity of the vSAN datastore?

discussion.content: The answer C is correct if you think only about Capacity where we have 10 nodes with 7 disks with 4 TB, this way 10 * 28 TB per node = 280 TB raw to be used by vSAN Cluster
C is the correct because if you consider a Hybrid cluster using 7 magnetic disks + 1 SSD disk for each node, the SSD is only for cache not for capacity. 7disks (4TB each) x 10 nodes = 280 TB
C for sure

C is right.

Total Capacity of host = 7 x 4TB = 28 TB
Total Capacity of Cluster = 10 x 28 TB = 280 TB
yes 280, C is correct
The answer A is correct if you think only about Capacity where we have 10 nodes with 7 disks with 4 TB, this way 10 * 28 TB per node = 280 TB raw to be used by vSAN Cluster

comments.content: Your math is right, but I am sure you meant to say the answer is C.

choices.B: Cache-to-capacity ratio needs to be sized lower
choices.A: Cache disk needs to meet vSAN Compatibility Guide
choices.D: Number of cache disks in disk group is insufficient.
choices.C: Cache-to-capacity ratio needs to be sized higher

comments.content:
The flash caching device must provide at least 10 percent of the 
anticipated storage that virtual machines are expected to consume, not 
including replicas such as mirrors.
so it must be 1.8 rather than 1.2 , correct me if im wrong
C is correct , but i think we shoulf look at the used capacity not the raw capacity cuz it might be used for either storage and data protection
In this case you have Only 1.2 TB cache because there are no required cache disks to reach 3 cache devices per node * 4 nodes to be compliance with the 10% cache required as per vSAN Design Guide

discussion.content:
I think Answer C is correct.
As a guideline, VMware recommends having at least a 10% flash cache to consumed capacity ratio in Hybrid vSAN configurations. 
If you have 36TB capacity, you will need 3,6TB cache - But there you only have 1,2 TB cache.
The easiest way to calculate it is Diskgroup Raw capacity * 10% = Cache size. In this case the cache is to small
I vote C because it looks like they forgot to multiply capacity disks per host to get the cluster number. Cluster capacity is only 5 disks for capacity and is wrong.

Selected Answer: C
is correct
C is correct as per comments

total cach capacity by cluster should be 4.8 and not 3.6 as mentioned in the post 
the correct answer is C

B.
Cache to Capacity ratio needs to be lower. A "low ratio" means a larger-sized cache drive compared to capacity. I think it's a trick question, which is silly because this exam should be to ensure we know the content, not trick us with words.

Here is a reference to VMware calling it "high ratio" meaning you need more cache:
https://core.vmware.com/resource/vmware-vsan-design-guide#sec4-sub6

The correct answer is C.

Best practice: Ensure there is enough cache to meet the design requirements. The recommendation for cache is 10% of of the anticipated consumed storage capacity before the NumberOfFailuresToTolerate is considered.

If the RAW Capacity for each host is 36TB then the cache should be 3.6 TB for each host.

https://core.vmware.com/resource/vmware-vsan-design-guide#sec5-sub5

The correct answer is C.

Best practice: Ensure there is enough cache to meet the design requirements. The recommendation for cache is 10% of of the anticipated consumed storage capacity before the NumberOfFailuresToTolerate is considered.

https://core.vmware.com/resource/vmware-vsan-design-guide#sec5-sub5

I agree with what was written before.
but using larger cache disks means making cache-capacity ratio "lower", i think.
So, I choose B.
you have 12 DG per cluster and 12 flashing devices, so correct, but undersized cache disk
I thing C is correct, cache is undersized on that diskgroups, Vsan disk groups only need a cache disk correctly sized, but take into account that on all flash the limit of usable cache is 600GB

comments.content: Last row of first table states required cluster cache capacity is 3.6(equates to 9 disks) however with 12 cache drives of 400GB, it should be 4.8 so chache is incorrectly sized. Correct answer is D
You have 3 Diskgroups per Nodes and also have 3 Chace Devices per Node. For the Cluster you need 12 cache Devices.

discussion.content: I think the D is correct, once you have 4 nodes into vSAN Cluster you are going to need 4 cache devices, one per disk group.

choices.D: Provides the ability to adjust the MTU

discussion.content:
Information Got from the Vmware deploy manual training :
 • Simplifies management by abstracting networks. • Reduces the amount of manual work and opportunity for mistakes. • Allows the use of Network I/O Control. • vSAN includes distributed switch licensing.
I guess the correct answer is A

I'm not sure if D is the correct answer. Standard Switches also allow configuring MTU.
Maybe A is the correct answer.
I agree A is the answer and it is NOT vSAN specific but more the features of Distributed switch in all circumstances

Selected Answer: A
Rest all options are invalid.
B, C and D is also covered by standard vswitches. So A.

A is the correct answer.

vSphere Distributed Switch has several benefits over standard switches:

• Simplifies management by abstracting networks.
• Reduces the amount of manual work and opportunity for mistakes.
• Allows the use of Network I/O Control.
• vSAN includes distributed switch licensing.

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - vSAN with vSphere Distributed Switch section
i'll go with A
i think it's A

If I had to choose an answer would be the answer A, but by discard. The answer should be "The benefit of using vSphere Distributed Switch is that it supports Network I/O Control which supports prioritization of bandwidth if contention occurs."

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of using vSphere Distributed Switches in a vSAN network?

An all-flash vSAN cluster contains four nodes.
Which two storage policies can the cluster satisfy? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
is correct
C and D correct

C & D are right

The required number of hosts for RAID 1 is 2n+1 while for RAID5/6 is 2n+2, so with 4 host just can support FTT=1 in RAID 1 [2(1)+1=3 host] and FTT=1 in RAID 5 [2(1)+2=4 hosts]
I agree with answer C and D using RAID 1 and RAID 5 with FTT = 1

Right answer

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vsphere.vmc-aws-manage-data-center-vms.doc/GUID-EDBB551B-51B0-421B-9C44-6ECB66ED660B.html
May be A & E

Selected Answer: AE
Is correct
A and E i believe are correct

Actually A and C and E are correct, i think.
but vROps is not mentioned in ebook as vsan interoperable software.
so, should be A and C.

comments.content: Live Optics is a a non-vmware product not used for troubleshooting. A & E are the only sensible choices here - vRealize has dashboard for vSAN, and integrates completely with it via the vSphere adapter.

discussion.content: A - E is correct
The correct answer is A and E where you can view erros, logs and analytic informations using both together.

questions.question_text:
A company implements a vSAN environment with linked clone virtual desktops and homogeneous desktop operating systems. During the last three months, users have experienced intermittent high latency, degraded performance, and lockout from desktops.
Which two methods should an administrator use to monitor and respond to the issues? (Choose two.)
